article.title: Spatially-resolved spectroscopy of narrow-line Seyfert 1 host galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the AGN deblending process illustrated in Figure 1?
choices: To remove the contribution of foreground stars from the data.
To separate the emission from the AGN and the host galaxy.
To measure the point-spread function (PSF) of the telescope.
To identify the location of the black hole in the galaxy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the red line in the upper panels of Figure 2 represent?
choices: The continuum emission from the AGN.
The best-fitting model to the nuclear spectrum.
The contribution of Fe II emission.
The residuals after subtracting the model from the data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the line ratio diagrams (bottom left panels) in Figure 3 suggest about the dominant source of gas ionization in the host galaxies?
choices: The gas is predominantly ionized by the AGN.
The gas is predominantly ionized by shocks.
The gas is predominantly ionized by star formation.
The gas ionization mechanism varies significantly across the host galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different symbols in Figure 5 represent?
choices: Different types of galaxies, such as spirals, ellipticals, and irregulars.
Different redshift ranges for the galaxies.
Different star formation rates for the galaxies.
Different measurement methods for the stellar mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in the oxygen abundance maps (Figure 6) for the two galaxies with sufficient data quality?
choices: The oxygen abundance is highest near the center of the galaxy and decreases with increasing galactocentric distance.
The oxygen abundance is lowest near the center of the galaxy and increases with increasing galactocentric distance.
The oxygen abundance is constant across the galaxy.
No clear trend in oxygen abundance is observed.
